facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1477 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1477 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 6, 1966 of Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 236 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 6, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 236 of 1961.

facts.text: Assessee was shareholder of companies engaged in managing hotels and was Director and Managing Director of various companies.

anchor.surface_text: The assesses who is the appellant was at all material times a share-holder of a number of companypanies engaged in the business of managing Hotels. He had also been a Director

facts.text: Assessee owned large block of shares of Spencers Hotel Limited and was its Managing Director in charge at material time.

anchor.surface_text: and Managing Director of various companypanies. Gradually he came to own a large block of shares of Spencers Hotel Limited and also became its Managing Director. He was incharge

facts.text: Assessee purchased interest in Associated Hotels of India Limited in 1938 in association with M. S. Oberoi.

anchor.surface_text: of the Management thereof at the material time. He further purchased interest in Associated Hotels of India Limited Hotels 1938 in association with M. S. Oberoi.

facts.text: In 1944, M. S. Oberoi purchased assessee's shareholding in Associated Hotels of India Limited for Rs.20,657,05/13/0.

anchor.surface_text: In 1944, M. S. Oberoi purchased from the assessee his share holding in the Associated Hotels of India Limited for an amount of Rs.20,657,05/13/0.

facts.text: In or about 1949, holding in Hotels 1938 Limited was purchased by M. S. Oberoi from assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly in or about 1949, the holding in Hotels 1938 Limited was purchased by the said M. S. Oberoi.

facts.text: Assessee disclosed receipt from sale of shares in Associated Hotels to ITO during assessment for 1945-46 and it was held capital receipt not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: It was maintained by the assessee that he has ,filed returns of his income in respect of the relevant assessment years and that during the assessment for the year 1945-46, the assessee had disclosed to the Income-tax Officer, District II, 2 Calcututa that he had received the aforesaid amount for the sale of the shares of the Asso- ciated Hotels. The amount was held to be a capital receipt on which numberincome tax was payable.

facts.text: Assessee showed interest received on Rs. 20,657,05/13/0 in returns of subsequent years.

anchor.surface_text: During the subsequent years, the assessee companytinued to show in his returns the interest received on the amount of Rs. 20,657,05/13/0.

facts.text: M. S. Oberoi's case referred to Investigation Commission under Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the case of M. S. Oberoi was referred to the Investigation Commission set up under the Taxation on Income Investigation Commission Act, 1947.

facts.text: Assessee served notice by Commission on or about 18th August 1951 under section 5(4) for assessment year 1940-41.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was also served a numberice by the Commission on or about 18th August, 1951 under section 5 4 of the aforesaid Act, in respect of the assessment year 1940-41.

facts.text: Assessee filed writ petition in March 1953 in Punjab High Court Circuit Bench Delhi to quash Commission proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed a Writ Petition in March, 1953 in the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench Delhi to quash the proceedings before the said Commission.

facts.text: Solicitor General undertook that all proceedings against assessee would be dropped, rule discharged.

anchor.surface_text: According to the assessee, the Solicitor General, who appeared in the High Court after a rule had been issued, gave an undertaking that all proceedings against the assessee would be dropped. Upon such undertaking being given, the rule was discharged.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer District II(2) Calcutta issued seven notices dated 5th November 1954 under S.34(1A) of IT Act 1922 for assessment years 1940-41 to 1946-47 alleging escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, District 11 2 Calcutta issued seven numberices dated 5th November, 1954 to the assessee under S. 34 1-A of the Income Tax Act, 1922 in respect of assessment years 1940-41 to 1946-47 alleging therein that the appellant had partly escaped assessment.

facts.text: ITO proceeded to make assessments for 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46 despite assessee objection on jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of the objection of the assessee that in the absence of any material on record, the Income Tax Officer had numberjurisdiction to issue any numberice under 34 1-A , the said Officer proceeded to make assessment in respect of the assessment years 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45 and 1945-46.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner who remanded to ITO for report including on fresh material to treat Rs.20,00,000 as income.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax who remanded the case to the Income Tax Officer to submit a report on various matters. One of such matters was that the Income Tax Officer should state as to what fresh material was before him to satisfy him that the sum of Rs. 20,00,000/- which was previously treated as capital should be treated as income.

facts.text: In 1961, assessee filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Calcutta High Court challenging AAC order, dismissed on 6th October 1966.

anchor.surface_text: In 1961, the assessee filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Calcutta High Court challenging the order of the Appellate Assistant Commis- sioner. This Writ Petition was dismissed on 6th October, 1966.

facts.text: In writ petition para 22(v), assessee claimed ITO had no material for s.34(1A) notice, only disclosed capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: In clause v of Para 22 of the Writ Petition, the assessee had stated that at the time when the numberice had been issued under S. 34 1-A of the Act, the Income Tax Officers companycerned did number have any material before them companystituting reason to believe that any income, profits or gains of the assessee had escaped assessment for any year. It was asserted that the only material before the Income Tax Officers companycerned on which they had purported to issue the numberices companysisted of the fact of the receipt of about Rs. 22,00,000/- which the assessee had received for the sale of his shares in the Associated Hotels of India Limited in the year 1944 that receipt had already been disclosed to the Income Tax Officer who had made the original assessment relating to the year 1945-46 and he had held that the said amount was a capital receipt.

facts.text: Reply affidavit denied that conditions precedent for s.34(1A) not fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: There was merely a denial in the affidavit in reply with reference to paragraph 22 v , that the companyditions precedent to the exercise of power under S. 34 1-A had number been fulfilled.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court held preconditions of s.34(1A) fulfilled, notices valid.

anchor.surface_text: It was finally held that the assessee had failed to establish that the preconditions companytained in S. 34 1-A had number been fulfilled and companysequently there was an initial lack of jurisdiction.

facts.text: Reasons recorded by ITO for s.34(1A): assessee believed to have made secret profits with Oberois, received Rs.22 lakhs from Oberois which escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The reason for such belief, inter alia, is as follows - The assessee who is or was at the relevant time a Managing Director in about a dozen limited companypanies, along with Oberois is believed to have made some secret profits which were number offered for assessment. The assessee is believed to have received a sum of Rs. 22 lakhs from Oberois,and this sum or at least part of which represents income has escaped assessment. Sd - A. K. BHOWMIK Income-tax Officer Distt. 11 2 , Calcutta.

facts.text: Supreme Court held reasons for ITO's belief inadequate, did not satisfy s.34(1A) requirements, notices illegal and invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the requirements of S. 34 1-A were number satisfied and, therefore, the numberices which had been issued were wholly illegal and invalid.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and set aside Calcutta High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Section 34  1-A  to the extent it is necessary, may be reproduced. 34  1-A . if, in the- case of any assessee, the income-tax officer has reason to believe- that income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment for any year in respect of which the relevant previous year falls and that the income, profits or gains which have so escaped assessment for any such year or years amount or are likely to amount to one lakh of rupees or more he may serve on the assessee a notice containing and may proceed to assess or reassess the income, profits or gains of the assessee Provided that the Income-tax Officer shall not issue a notice under this sub-section unless he has recorded his reasons for doing so and the Central Board of Revenue is satisfied on such reasons recorded that it is a fit case for the issue of such notice.

concepts.interpretation: Requirements not satisfied as reasons were inadequate, mere suspicion without material facts; notices illegal and invalid

anchor.surface_text: There can be no manner of doubt that the words reason to believe suggest that the belief must be that of an honest and reasonable person based upon reasonable grounds and that the Income Tax Officer may act on direct or circumstantial evidence but not on mere suspicion, gossip or rumour. The Income Tax Officer would be acting without jurisdiction if the reason for his belief that the conditions are satisfied does not exist or is not material or relevant to the , belief required by the section. The court can always examine this aspect though the declaration or sufficiency of the reasons for the belief cannot be investigated by the court.

concepts.interpretation: Belief must be honest, reasonable, on reasonable grounds/direct or circumstantial evidence; court can examine existence/relevance of reasons but not sufficiency; applied to hold ITO reasons inadequate

issues.text: Whether the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction to issue notices and make assessments under Section 34(1A) of the Income Tax Act, 1922, i.e., whether he had reason to believe that income chargeable to tax had escaped assessment amounting to or likely to amount to one lakh rupees or more

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dealt with several points which were raised on behalf of the assessee which included the question whether the Income Tax Officer had the jurisdiction to make an assessment under the provisions of S. 34 unless the, conditions contained in S. 34 1-A were satisfied. In other words, unless he had reason to believe thatincome profits or gains chargeable to income had escaped assess-

issues.text: Whether the writ petition under Article 226 was maintainable after the assessee had invoked the alternative statutory remedy of appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in the first place sustained a preliminary objection which had been raised on behalf of the revenue that because the assessee had filed appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, he could not pursue his petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court.

issues.text: Whether Section 34(1A) of the Income Tax Act, 1922 is valid and constitutional

anchor.surface_text: The other points which had been canvassed related to the validity and constitutionality of S. 34 1-A . The High Court held that it had been settled by a series of decisions of this Court that it was not unconstitutional.

issues.text: Whether the court could examine the recorded reasons for the Income Tax Officer's belief to determine jurisdictional compliance under Section 34(1A)

The Income Tax Officer would be acting without jurisdiction if the reason for his belief that the conditions are satisfied does not exist or is not material or relevant to the , belief required by the section.

holdings.text: The requirements of Section 34(1A) of the Income Tax Act, 1922 were not satisfied and the notices issued thereunder were wholly illegal and invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the requirements of S. 34 1-A were number satisfied and, therefore, the numberices which had been issued were wholly illegal and invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recorded reasons consisted of bare beliefs without material facts or evidence, amounting to mere suspicion; self-contradictory and analogous to inadequate reasons in Chhugamal Rajpal case.

holdings.text: The words 'reason to believe' require the belief to be that of an honest and reasonable person based upon reasonable grounds; the Income Tax Officer can act on direct or circumstantial evidence but not on mere suspicion, gossip or rumour.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numbermanner of doubt that the words reason to believe suggest that the belief must be that of an honest and reasonable person based upon reasonable grounds and that the Income Tax Officer may act on direct or circumstantial evidence but number on mere suspicion, gossip or rumour.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation affirmed by prior decisions; applied to hold ITO's reasons inadequate as lacking material foundation.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer acts without jurisdiction if the reason for his belief does not exist or is not material or relevant to the belief required by Section 34(1A); the court can examine the existence and relevance of such reasons though not their sufficiency.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer would be acting without jurisdiction if the reason for his belief that the companyditions are satisfied does number exist or is number material or relevant to the , belief required by the section. The companyrt can always examine this aspect though the declaration or sufficiency of the reasons for the belief cannot be investigated by the companyrt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdictional fact review permitted to ensure compliance; court examined ITO's recorded reasons and found them wanting.

holdings.text: The law laid down in Chhugamal Rajpal case is fully applicable to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, the law laid down by this Court in the above case is fully applicable to the facts of the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts analogous: ITO reasons vague, based on vague communications without stating material leading to belief of escapement.

holdings.text: The two reasons given by the Income Tax Officer for his belief hopelessly fail to satisfy the requirements of Section 34(1A).

anchor.surface_text: It is abundantly clear that the two reasons which have been given for the belief which was formed by the Income Tax Officer hopelessly fail to satisfy the requirements of the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasons stated as 'beliefs' without facts (secret profits, receipt from Oberois); no material to form reasonable belief of escapement.

holdings.text: The Supreme Court will examine the question under Section 34(1A) as the High Court decided it on merits, making it binding on lower authorities.

anchor.surface_text: Since the High Court gave a decision on that matter, which would be binding on the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, we are unable to accede to the submission made by the learned companynsel for the revenue that we should decline to go into, the question arising out of the provisions of S. 34 1-A .

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court sustained alternative remedy objection but proceeded to merits; decision binding below.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.
